security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based documentation skill with no executable code. Only contains markdown files providing guidance for handling git worktree operations via Claude Code built-in slash commands.

content.user_title: Manage Git Worktrees for Parallel Development
content.value_statement: Managing multiple development branches simultaneously is complex and error-prone. This skill provides slash commands to safely create, list, and remove git worktrees with automatic port allocation and service management.
actual_capabilities: Create git worktrees with automatic port allocation
List all worktrees with status and service information
Remove worktrees with automatic cleanup of services
Handle port conflicts by calculating unique offsets
Manage background processes for server and client
Set up isolated configuration for each worktree
limitations: Only works with git repositories that have worktree support enabled
Requires existing branches to create worktrees from
Cannot manage worktrees outside the `trees/` directory convention
Depends on Claude Code slash commands being available

use_cases.title: Parallel Feature Work
use_cases.description: Work on multiple features simultaneously without stashing or switching branches

use_cases.title: Review PRs in Isolation
use_cases.description: Test pull requests in isolated environments before merging

use_cases.title: Hotfix While Developing
use_cases.description: Apply production fixes while continuing feature development

prompt_templates.prompt: Create a worktree for the [branch-name] branch

prompt_templates.title: List Worktrees
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me my current worktrees and their status

prompt_templates.title: Remove Worktree
prompt_templates.prompt: Remove the [branch-name] worktree, I am done with it

prompt_templates.title: Parallel Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Create worktrees for feature-a, feature-b, and feature-c so I can work on all three

output_examples.input: Create a worktree for the feature-authentication branch

best_practices: Remove worktrees promptly after merging to free up ports and disk space
Use descriptive branch names that match your git workflow convention
List worktrees regularly to identify abandoned or stuck environments
anti_patterns: Manually editing worktree files instead of using slash commands
Creating worktrees for quick one-line changes when git checkout suffices
Leaving worktrees running when not actively developing on them

faq.question: What tools is this skill compatible with?
faq.answer: Works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. Requires slash command support.

faq.question: How many worktrees can I create?
faq.answer: Limited by available ports and disk space. Port offsets support dozens of worktrees.

faq.question: Does this integrate with existing git workflows?
faq.answer: Yes, uses standard git worktree commands and fits any git-based workflow.

faq.question: Is my data safe in worktrees?
faq.answer: Worktrees share git history but have isolated file systems and configurations.

faq.question: Why are my services not starting?
faq.answer: Check port conflicts with `/list_worktrees` or recreate the worktree if processes crashed.

faq.question: How is this different from git checkout?
faq.answer: Worktrees allow multiple branches simultaneously without switching or stashing changes.
